Far from the Tree by Robin Benway

I really enjoyed reading this book. The writing was very good. The change of povâ€™s between the siblings was a great idea. It has some serious and very real situations without it being too heavy for the reader. It has a good balance of family, love, loss, and friendship.
Definitely recommend reading it

.
Kako se to kod nas kaÅ¾e, iver ne pada daleko od klade. Ovo je priÄa o porodici, o razumevanju, o onom neÄem jedinstvenom i neobjaÅ¡njivom Å¡to nas veÅ¾e za naÅ¡e najbliÅ¾e.
.
Grejs ima 16 godina i nedavno se porodila i dala svoju tek roÄ‘enu bebu na usvajanje. Jedino ko bi je razumeo, i koga ona tek sad razume, jeste njena bioloÅ¡ka majka koja ju je dala na usvajanje Äim se rodila. Grejs odluÄuje da je potraÅ¾i, ali prvo saznaje da ima sestru i brata.
.
Njih troje se upoznaju, zbliÅ¾avaju i reÅ¡avaju da naÄ‘u bioloÅ¡ku majku. Svo troje prolaze kroz teÅ¡ke trenutke u Å¾ivotu i po prvu put oseÄ‡aju da nisu sami, da imaju nekog svog na koga se mogu osloniti, iako su do juÄe bili stranci.
.
Meni je ova knjiga bila predivna i optimistiÄna, mada me je na trenutke zaista rastuÅ¾ila. Moram da istaknem dva vaÅ¾na utiska:
.
Prvo, ova knjiga nas uÄi o znaÄaju porodice, koju niÅ¡ta ne moÅ¾e da zameni. Krv je neÅ¡to od Äega ne moÅ¾emo pobeÄ‡i. ÄŒak i kad ne opravdavamo njihove postupke, rodbini uvek moramo biti rame za plakanje.
.
Drugo je taj ceo proces odvajanja majke od deteta. Knjiga nam doÄarava ovu temu iz dva ugla: devojke koja je ceo Å¾ivot osuÄ‘ivala majku koja ju je napustila, a potom te iste devojke koja napuÅ¡ta svoje dete. TakoÄ‘e pratimo porodice svo troje glavnih likova, i kako se oni prilagoÄ‘avaju usvojenom detetu.
.
Kroz knjigu sam preispitala svoje stavove o porodici i napuÅ¡tanju/usvajanju dece. Mislim da sam dosta nauÄila i ostala joÅ¡ u mislima sa nekim pitanjima na koja valjda i ne postoji odgovor.
.
Na kraju, postavlja se pitanje Å¡ta uopÅ¡te znaÄi biti porodica? Da li je to krvno srodstvo ili zapravo bilo kakva veza koja nas tera da uvek budemo tu jedni za druge, da se podrÅ¾avamo i bezrezervno volimo?
.

Book 3 of 2022. Far from the Tree by Robin Benway.
This is the April @beeyogafusion book club book. I put it on hold at my library, and it was supposed to be ready in 2 months, but then I got it earlier. Hence why Iâ€™m posting about it now. 
Anyway, I donâ€™t want to give too much away, but I will say this- I loved this book!
I loved the characters, seeing them navigate their relationships with each other and internally. Highly recommend giving this a read and then joining us for conversation via zoom.
Ps- have tissues nearby; the last three chapters are a doozy!

||Far from the Tree|| Review||
Words canâ€™t describe how much I loved this book! This book is 375 pages of pure love, friendship and so much more!
.
.
ğŸ“š description: Being the middle child has its ups and downs.

But for Grace, an only child who was adopted at birth, discovering that she is a middle child is a different ride altogether. After putting her own baby up for adoption, she goes looking for her biological family, includingâ€”

Maya, her loudmouthed younger bio sister, who has a lot to say about their newfound family ties. Having grown up the snarky brunette in a house full of chipper redheads, sheâ€™s quick to search for traces of herself among these not-quite-strangers. And when her adopted familyâ€™s long-buried problems begin to explode to the surface, Maya canâ€™t help but wonder where exactly it is that she belongs.

And Joaquin, their stoic older bio brother, who has no interest in bonding over their shared biological mother. After seventeen years in the foster care system, heâ€™s learned that there are no heroes, and secrets and fears are best kept close to the vest, where they canâ€™t hurt anyone but him.
.
.
I rate this book 5 â­ï¸. I highly recommend this book if anyone is a YA reader, someone who loves the show This is Us and for someone who loves books about family. .
.

This book, Far From The Tree, is a must read for everyone in the helping field. The mug will help a little bit. ğŸ˜Š 
But seriously this book helps us become more empathetic towards people whose lives have been affected by deafness, dwarfism, Down Syndrome, Autism, Schizophrenia, Disability, Prodigies, Rape, Crime and Transgender.

Any of us can be a better version of himself, but none of us can be someone else.

Mainstreaming, inclusion, deinstitutionalization, the disability rights movement, identity politics - all these forces both emphasize and normalize difference.

Our most basic needs are all the same - to be accepted for who we are.

Building a compassionate society benefits not only those who are newly tolerated, but also those who are newly tolerating. 
#acceptance #tolerance #empathy #acceptance #love #bookstagram #books #bookshelves #psychology #farfromthetree #farfromthetreebook #family #autism #deafcommunity #dwarfism #downsyndrome #schizophrenia #transgender

Book: Far From The Tree

Author: Robin Benway @robinbenway 

Personal rating: 5/5

The beginning of the book was so promising and the plot was so good except that in the middle it somewhat felt like the author had lost direction to some extent. Some places felt deliberate and some things exaggerated and some things too good to be true, but overall a really good book. I could really feel the emotions depicted in the book. Definitely recommend it.

when i found these books i didnâ€™t know what to expect. Far From The Tree is a beautiful story about finding your family, and the realities of adoption. i read it a long time ago, but still remember feeling content. the writing was beautiful and poignant, and i would love to be able to read it for the first time again. 
the same can be said for The Places Iâ€™ve Cried In Public. the writing was phenomenal, and introduced my to the amazing imagination of Holly Bourne. sheâ€™s now one of my faves. and it has purple sprayed edges!..

what was the book that introduced you to a particular author?

-Robin Benway
.
ğŸ“–Book: Far From The Tree
âœ’Author: Robin Benway
.
ğŸ”®: One typical day, a "bomb" crash-lands onto you as such: "You have biological siblings who you don't/may not know of, as of yet and they are on their way to meet you." This is precisely what happened to the leads. 
.
Three complete strangers are actually not strangers at all. Soon enough, they learn that they're all biological siblings and they start a whole new journey to locate their biological mother while trying to find homes in each other on the way.
.
The story kept unwinding, revealing their flaws, vulnerabilities, trust issues, fear of being judged, fear of not being loved and accepted for who they were or being able to love, uncertainties about each of their choices and their consequences, and above all the question tearing at their hearts of what it truly means to be a family.
.
 It was very, very well-written and the character developments and transitions were striking. The entire "teen- phase-situation" was described in a highly frustrating way but was authentic. You'll know why if you read it. There are a lot of diverse elements in the book like teen pregnancy, racism, dysfunctional family, substance abuse, bullying, etc. and I appreciated how the author accomplished to wrap up everything so evenly. 
.
The way they explore and open up to each other about their lives, their bond blooming overtime, the flashes and glimpses of affection slowly turning into the fierce, unexplainable love that ties a family together, and the intense feelings which hold one another was exhibited beautifully. I loved itğŸ¥ºğŸ˜­. I can't sum it up correctly, there were way too many elements and heart-wrecking emotions, however, with a sense of hope and fulfillment beneath it all. Also omg? Rafe was just the perfect funny+sweet punch to the story, love that guyğŸ˜³.

I made my family wait while I tried to find a good place to take this picture so Iâ€™m posting it today!  Itâ€™s not quite what i envisioned, but I like this lamp in the background. I last read In Five Years weeks ago!  It was the perfect end of summer break book and I enjoyed laying in the hammock and ignoring all chores to find out how it would resolve!  Upon finishing, I would have probably given it five stars, but since at least two weeks has elapsed and I havenâ€™t given this book a second thought, my true rating might be â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ğŸ’«. It was an enjoyable read and I liked the friendship at the center of the book.

After floundering for the last two weeks and reading maybe a paragraph before falling asleep and turning off audiobooks when I realized I hadnâ€™t heard a word that was said, Writers and Lovers has held my attention!  Iâ€™m really enjoying Lily Kingâ€™s writing.

Iâ€™m not sure whatâ€™s next, but a new mom friend is reading Far From the Tree with a friend and has told me several times that I should read along with her. Iâ€™m a month behind, and the size is daunting with the current state of my concentration. I remember Book Riot recommended this on a gift show several years ago so the subject matter interests me. I may need to buy this one to mark it up, but I ran into my new mom friend at the library and she pressed it into my hands. #infiveyears #writersandloversbook #farfromthetreebook

Synopsis: Being the middle child has its ups and downs.
But for Grace, an only child who was adopted at birth, discovering that she is a middle child is a different ride altogether. After putting her own baby up for adoption, she goes looking for her biological family, includingâ€”
Maya, her loudmouthed younger bio sister, who has a lot to say about their newfound family ties. Having grown up the snarky brunette in a house full of chipper redheads, sheâ€™s quick to search for traces of herself among these not-quite-strangers. And when her adopted familyâ€™s long-buried problems begin to explode to the surface, Maya canâ€™t help but wonder where exactly it is that she belongs.
And Joaquin, their stoic older bio brother, who has no interest in bonding over their shared biological mother. After seventeen years in the foster care system, heâ€™s learned that there are no heroes, and secrets and fears are best kept close to the vest, where they canâ€™t hurt anyone but him.
